Hi everyone, so while I am not aware of any specific policy regarding the debug/info/trace logging level(s)...
We should probably have the server/services print out more than just '.... Started.'
I'm fine with keeping using the `Info.Println()`, however, we can also use other modes.

E.g., 
INFO: 2016/06/30 20:05:32 Staring ACA...
INFO: 2016/06/30 20:05:32 Public ACA gRPC started.
....
INFO: 2016/06/30 20:05:33 ACA Started.


INFO: 2016/06/30 20:05:35 Stopping ACA...
...
INFO: 2016/06/30 20:05:34 Public ACA gRPC stopped.
INFO: 2016/06/30 20:05:35 ACA Stopped .
But if there are any concerns/suggestions regarding the level of detail, it's easy to move some of these to DEBUG level, or so.

We're (<@U1MHRQT4J>) exploring hyperledger Fabric and we've discovered a strange behavior with the login mechanism.  Using the REST API 
1. We've logged in to a peer node with a credential and we couldn't login to another peer node with the same credential
2. We couldn't find a way to logout a user
3. The state of the login is sticky to a particular peer node (eg, logged in nodeA, cannot perform transaction in nodeB)
4. When we tried to restart a peer node with the same credential, it didn't work (maybe the member service thinks the node_user is still logged in?)
Is there a way to share security context between peer nodes?  Is it possible to logout a user?  Any help is appreciated.  Thanks!

<@U1B5DPRLG|lhaskins> has joined the channel

Moving "
cbruguera
5:23 PM However, I was pondering how crazy it was to rely the certificate handling to the network itself... Like taking the CA code and make it into smart contracts, maybe using some sort of "shared computation", so that the "authority" is the network, truly decentralizing certificate issuance (even within a permissioned network, decentralization is important)" here
:slightly_smiling_face:
(from <#C0Y4PEU22>)
The thing is, I wanna implement a network for KYC and proof of identity.
So to elaborate a bit on your question, these various CAs have logical functionality
alright..
Along with some 'physical' ones, right?
Right.
Practically, each has a 'private' (signing) key
And others should know about/trust its 'public' (verification) key, right?
Right.
That's the physical/practical PKI kind of world.
Now when you say the `CA code` in
" Like taking the `CA code` and make it into smart contracts, maybe using some sort of "shared computation", so that the "authority" is the network"
The first thing that springs to mind is a conditional behaviour
Tied to a (smart) contract.
That is, if conditions (A + B | C) are met, then a CSR is made with some attributes.
E.g., in the KYC world,
Yep.
Say if somebody could confirm his 'Home Address', 'Phone Number', bank account or whatever
There is an approval or some process (in the physical world)... that is connected to the 'digital' world, such that a smart contract can refer to that data point, and take it into an account
... and so the 'engine' on which that smart contract is evaluate/executed can process the 'next step' in the contract.
For now, let's even think the approval process is also digital. :slightly_smiling_face:
I'd look at such an update as an external (state-changing) input
You can tie it to a smart contract, yes.
I want everything to occur in the "digital" world. So it won't be complicated to tie such conditions to smart contracts. Therefore, I don't want to rely on "out of band" certificate handling.
OK, this simplifies a lot, I agree. Go on...
What does sound a bit complicated (at least for my technical expertise) is that about taking the CA logic and decentralize it.
Just to caution on one thing, re: `certificate handling`
Do you want to do EVERYTHING with certificates?
I wouldn't.
Hmmm not sure
At least some types of certificates.
OK. While I don't know everything about the solution (nor the problem ;-))
... you can have the 'critical' steps that require approval, using certificates.
... and delegate a lot of responsibility!
Let's say ECA is a centralized point, but I want the TCerts to be generated as a shared computation among many peers.
That's a key feature. Subtle, but huge.
Yeah.
Just playing with my imagination. :slightly_smiling_face:
No problem. I'm following [so far! ;-)]
I think I'm into something here, but my technical knowledge of the platform is still too green.
Say 10 users enrolled, each has a pretty, shiny, fresh Enrollment Cert. Go on.
[Deep inside, I'm trying to see if you are looking at a form of a threshold signature/multi-sig model, but go on]

OK, let's say one of those users is an auditor, and he requests access to another user's documents... The user approves such access, therefore a TCert should be granted to this auditor that allows him to check on the relevant data...
Such TCert could be generated by a smart contract. That's what I mean...
So, say User 10 is the auditor.
What I'm not sure of, is what potential security breaches does that bring.
You want User1 to grant User10 the ability to look at User1's documents?
[Don't worry about the security aspects yet. Let's focus on the use-case of what you are trying to do/achieve]
Yep, that's right.
Of course, I'm assuming user10 has a special ECert (or an ECert with metadata) that makes him an auditor and not a regular user.
NP. Not worried about that (for now). `User10` is the auditor.
`User1` trusts `User10`'s identity, etc.... and say, can grant him the access to these docs.
Cool, so far?
Yep
The question is HOW to do this, right?
only one problem... It's dinner time here.
hehe
OK. [+2 units of complexity added here:] are these documents hashed anywhere on the/a chain?
(yeah, they should be hashed somewhere indeed)

I'll be back later tonight (or maybe tomorrow)... This conversation is truly interesting and important for me, so let's resume later, ok?

Any remaining thoughts you have, I'll be glad to read them if you leave them here.

Thanks for the feedback!
[You see, there's always something that's still connected to the physical world!]
LOL
That's right.
We can continue tomorrow, either publicly here and/or privately.
I'll be back
thank you very much
NP. I'll just say quickly: you need both Authentication and Authorization.... and an Encryption scheme, other than just hashing.
[So that I don't forget]
Enjoy dinner Carlos.
<@U11MANG9G>: I'm back, I'll be on for some minutes, if you're still around, ping me. If not, let's resume this later. :slightly_smiling_face:

text: (in the client-sdk/GitHub)
I can (and will) probably add some comments on GitHub, but first, I'm also happy to discuss this here (first)
So Enrollment effectively conveys/provides one with an Enrollment Certificate (ECert)
It is a much stronger concept (to me), than a log-in/log-out...

Intuitively, the way I see/approach a request to 'delete my Enrollment' (especially from the DB), ... is similar to FB asking me if I would like to commit a `social suicide` when I'm asking to 'unenroll' from FB.
I'm happy to discuss this further (here), but if there are no objections/comments, I'll go ahead and put/add my thoughts/comments on the issue.
WDYT ?
yes, register/unregister is equivalent to addUser/removeUser which is much more than login/logout
Yup, it has to be... therefore, my inclination is not to be able to reuse the enrollment, nor the certificate. Happy to hear more thoughts, and then I'm off to GitHub :wink:

If the reason for unenrolling is because of suspected compromise or non-recoverable loss of the enrollment private key, the standard way to deal with this would be ECert revocation disseminated via CRL or OCSP/OCSP stapling so that relying parties can retrieve trusted notification. In that case, a user should be allowed to reenroll if they can provide the Registration Authority with fresh proof of ECert issuance eligibility, such as proof of UserID and Affiliation included within an issued ECert. There is also the issue of whether the same UserID or (effectively equivalent UserID) should be able to be associated with concurrently valid ECerts that each have distinct (proven eligibility/ownership) Affiliations.

Yes, I was thinking along these lines, which is why I used the `social suicide` example from FB - effectively, I view such DELETE request as the request to terminate the account. Keith put together a short list that I'll relate to as well (as to whom should be allowed to perform that action).
"my inclination is *not to be able to reuse the enrollment, nor the certificate*" == *certificate revocation* (in PKI terms, yes)

<@U16Q0J0E6>: I agree with the second part, but I'd focus on the first - as it seems to me
 i) more burning/important as we define requirements. We have the placeholders for the revocation, etc.
(ii) immediate need as we want to get the basic workflow working well.

That is, let's allow/focuson/get the dynamic enrollment + revocation to work first, then worry about the multiple EIDs per user, with or w/o proven Affiliations. (I do completely agree that it's important too, probably right after we handle the first part).
<@U11CP8FF1|ibmamnt> has joined the channel

Greetings!

I have a question: are _Registration_ _Authorities_ contemplated in the Fabric's role design or are these assumed to operate completely "out of band"?
Hey Carlos, the short version is that the registration authority functionality is designed to happily live “in band”...
Let me elaborate a bit...
Let’s look at the two registration authorities in the system by the type of due-diligence needed for generating/issuing a certificate.
Such functionality is needed before issuing ECerts and/or TCerts:

1. *Enrollment* Step
`UserID` & `Affiliation`

The attributes that are being validated by an RA are the `UserID` and the `Affiliation`… these are the two “special case attributes” in the ECerts (issued by the/an ECA).

2. *Transaction/Pre-Transaction*
The attributes that are being validated by the ACA are those that are to be included in the future/to-be-signed TCerts (issued by the/a TCA).

In the context of your earlier question/use case, I still believe that if everything is done digitally, then you should focus on the "in band" design/flow... these can still co-exist with web-of-trust like attestations.
<@U1QR80VM3|joonas> has joined the channel
<@U1G3WJ740|castlesb> has joined the channel
<@U11MANG9G>: So we would need to create a gRPC call in order to dynamically add/change/remove attributes?
Yes, currently we have that static list of attributes in the YAML
There are a few ongoing issues under discussions, the latest is the request to clean up a lot of test data, and have some more flexibility (e.g., for tests, examples... and of course; deployment)
The rest of the plumbing is there, and should not be very difficult to add that gRPC call. Happy to prioritize...
It's mostly to 'add' attributes. That is, a set/list of known attributes that can be requested.
The *hottest* example/attribute is probably *ACCOUNT_*
Account numbers, (sub?) account ID, etc.

Gotcha, I was looking at assetManagement02 and noticed that other than attributes being hard coded for new users, what if an attribute value needs to change (such as a user wanting to change email addresses for example) which led to my dynamic attributes question
Yes, you are not alone there. I don't like the static list of attributes either. In all honestly, it was put there temporarily, but we should follow up on it.
Now, a bit more specifically to your second part of the sentence...
There is a 'big' differentiation between one's identity and other attributes relating/associated with such an identity.
So, say on FB, there is only one `Jonathan Levi` corresponding to my email address... right? (hopefully)
But later on, I might be able to change my email address and still be the same person.
The reason I'm mentioning this is because it's important to define what's the unique identifier that is used to 'identify' a user (, organization or device?)
Now as an email is just an attribute that is added/associated with an identity, a separate question is how to establish/make/update/remove such link/association.
The 'easy' way, is to simply have it as a certificate/or an extension, and to revoke/re-issue on update.

It's 'easy' in terms of work that we need to do/API to support this (e.g., just issue a new certificate every time), but it's not really simple nor feasible in many cases (talking about IoT... for example).
I believe that we'll have to extend the stack... In other words, I'll prioritize this additional gRPC call :wink:

Hello, I have a couple of questions about today's presentation...

1) How are authorized auditors treated by the network from a permission point of view? Is there a particular (long term) TCert that makes them into auditors? By the way, what does it mean that auditing does not require action or interaction from validators? (taken from one of the slides). 2) Is "verify-only attribute access" some kind of zero-knowledge proof?
<@U11NUTP4L|srirama_sharma> has joined the channel

Hello <@U1ENXTQRL> regarding 1, an auditor could or could not be enrolled in the system, the idea is to have flexibility to not force the auditors to be participants of the network. The auditor will request access to a preK from the preK tree according to his jurisdiction. That key will allow the auditor to derivate keys to decrypt attributes from TCerts if the affiliation of that TCert falls into the auditor jurisdiction
this also means that auditors don't need interaction with validators

regarding 2, attributes are encrypted in a way that allows his owner to grant access to see the actual value or to grant access to only make questions against the value (somethink like: is the value of this attribute “X”, and the answer will be yes, or no, without revealing the actual value of the attribute)
hope it makes sense, if you have additional questions please feel free to ask :slightly_smiling_face:
Thanks <@U0XQX3U9G> !
Well, #2 sounds indeed like a "zero-knowledge proof", although I'm not acquainted with the implementation details to tell if we can formally call it that. In any case, that's a nice feature.
I agree with you, is not formally zero knowledge, but you can think of it as similar

but if I shutdown one node and try to restart it again (with the same id and password), an error occurs:
"Identity or token does not match"
It looks like the CA is trying to create new certificates
to which  it ends with such error
(which is not too clear, in my opinion)
shouldn't the membersrvc just try to login if credentials already exist, instead of trying to re-enroll?
(the same thing happens with users trying to enroll/login through a peer)
Hi OK, so first, congrats on getting this set up.
Second (and we do need to document this better!), are you trying to register twice?
There is this concept of a 'one-time-password' like logging in. Effectively the mode of work should be:
Enroll (get an ECert)
And then fetch a (or a few) TCerts...
There are a few tests that you can also look at, that effectively follow this logic.
There are unit tests (in Go) that I can point you to... but these are probably too low-level.
There are some integration 'Behave' tests in Python
There are some Client/Node SDK scenarios...
Most of them cover this:
Register -> Enroll -> Transact (and we do have different transaction types)
OK, let's start with the peer node example. I run a node with the info that allows it to enroll as a new validator on the network: success. Now I shut it down via Ctrl-C...
What next?
how do I re-start it without the membersvc trying to re-enroll it
Which example/code are you trying to run?
no code yet, only that simple manual test.
this is the command
Cool, I want to see what you are executing.

docker run --rm -it -e CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=<http://172.17.0.1:2375> -e CORE_PEER_ID=vp0 -e CORE_PEER_ADDRESSAUTODETECT=true -e CORE_SECURITY_ENABLED=true -e CORE_SECURITY_PRIVACY=true -e CORE_PEER_PKI_ECA_PADDR=172.17.0.1:50051 -e CORE_PEER_PKI_TCA_PADDR=172.17.0.1:50051 -e CORE_PEER_PKI_TLSCA_PADDR=172.17.0.1:50051 -e CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLID=vp0 -e CORE_SECURITY_ENROLLSECRET=vp0_secret  hyperledger/fabric-peer peer node start
(same thing as in the docs)
Hi <@U1ENXTQRL>, you cannot register twice, that is probably why you are seeing that message
yep
OK, so you are trying to use vp0 twice?
so once you enroll you just need to login
I understand that. But I want to know what's the correct command to "just login"
I see, let me share something with you
OK I tried re-running with the first command showed at the docs...
docker run --rm -it -e CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=<http://172.17.0.1:2375> -e CORE_PEER_ID=vp0 -e CORE_PEER_ADDRESSAUTODETECT=true hyperledger/fabric-peer peer node start
It works.
What I was wondering was... Does the peer automatically find all the PKI authorities' addresses?
So, is this peer connected to the membersvc?
First, thank you Diego. Carlos: It's a decentralized environment
Informally: Your CA is not your FB server
so for login in you are doing this, right? peer network login <username>
You use the CA/PKI for generating the Certs
Once enrolled....
You can continue with the EnrollID forward
the answer is yes <@U1ENXTQRL>, if you take a look at the core.yaml file you will see the address of the membership services configured there
But you don't need to Re ('create account')
so the peer knows how to find the membership services
Oh, I see...
(... and/but it does not stay 'connected')
Just to clarify Carlos.
It's just when you need to interact with it.
I see...
Hmmm that's good.
I picked on the word, just to clarify...
Yup, the mode is asynchronous... the client stores these certs and can continue even with/if the CA is "offline"
That was your first ever question to me, if I recall.
That's right.
Alright, got it.
Now, there's another test that I did...
I ran two nodes (with the long command, as they needed to enroll)
Just following the docs...
So, the second node, somehow connects to the network through the first node (I don't know if I got that right)
Then I shutdown the second node, and the first one kept on trying to re-connect to that "lost" node ad infinitum.
Is that a desirable behavior?
As I understand it, second peer connects through the first because of this option `CORE_PEER_DISCOVERY_ROOTNODE=172.17.0.2:30303`
(which is the IP address of the first node)

I could reproduce the error. Got a second node running with such option, shut it down, and the first node stays looping this error:

`Error creating connection to peer address 172.17.0.3:30303: grpc: timed out trying to connect`
forever.

<@U1ENXTQRL>
<http://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/dev-setup/devnet-setup/>
thanks!

I can't tell if it's related to Vagrant port forwarding configuration, or so. I suspect, but can't tell without you if that's related to `vagrant`s port forwarding... but we have many working examples of two (such) peer nodes in the tests...
Will document whatever we find. Have a good weekend Carlos! :wink:

Hi, so a few things... I think it would be more helpful to break down the Membership Services box into the services others are calling (I am assuming the RA is in the original box of Membership Services).
E.g., you get the ECert from the ECA, getting the TCert from the TCA.
The Membership Service box, in the diagram, changes in the next section to a Certificate Authority

In the diagram there is more back and forth between A(lice) and B(ob) than in real life (noting that the key exchange in Fabric is very different than the Bitcoin protocol, in case this is the/a source of confusion)
Most of the communication/exchanges in such systems is done through the Blockchain itself (and not directly between Alice and Bob)

I think that it's important to go into the Attributes (detail) of the Asset Transfer case, because that's where it's 1) more complicated 2) more important, and IMO, this is Fabric's Membership Services biggest strength.
I have a lot of diagrams that we used during the design/planning of some of these features... that I will happily share.
These might need some work/cleaning-up/updating, but as I said, I'd be super happy to work with others and contribute these back to the community.

Hi all,
I had one question regarding the login process and the subsequent operations on the basis of that..

my code base is a bit old, say June 29th cut.
Now i have written a client java program to login and deploy chaincode into HL
I run the client program in two machines which have ip addresses IP1 and IP2
now IP1 connects with jim and logs in and deploys the code
but IP1 has not logged out yet.
now after 2 min, IP2 connects and tries to log in with JIM itself. It gets a response "jim is already logged in"
but when IP2 tries to deploy - with the JIM - it works...  :disappointed:
i meant deploy, invoke, query - anything with JIM works from IP1 and IP2.
so what i m wondering is , is this the intended functionality ?
cos this one looks like impersonation to me - which can cause non-repudiation issues.
In a banking scenario, or trading scenario, this would mean any client in the chain can invoke Chaincode impersonating another client
Hi <@U0ULK2JPP> :wink:, and hello <@U1CS08EP3>
Hello..
You are right, and this is work in progress... (to allow the ability to logout)
Also, to allow authorized entities to also "kick someone out of the network"...
ohkay :slightly_smiling_face:
E.g., thinking about an admin user, revoking one's rights.
(For example, after misbehaving, or so... with or without consensus)
Keep in mind that this project is still in Incubation state... however, it is work in progress.
At the same time, the system is not that insecure.... actually.
Each user gets his "own" ECert, and then obtaining a TCert (which allows Transactions)
Here you are (to some extent) sharing the credentials... so it's not precisely impersonation, per se.
hmmm..
That is, it's not as if Jonathan can claim that he is Ashish. However, if Ashish provides Jonathan with his credentials...
(Here you used "Jim" twice, right?)
Here I used jim twice, first time login was successful, second time i got the " JIM already logged in error"
but second time, after I got the Jim already logged in error, from IP2, if I push an invoke, which had secure context stamped as JIM, it worked
that was the concern I had.
For the time being I am planning to use that registrar/DELETE api post each transaction so that unless I have JIM's password, I cant login and post transaction as JIM
without this, if JIM is logged in from IP1, even IP2 can post transaction as JIM
IP2 just have to guess that JIM has logged in from IP1.
We need to get a "softer" version of delete (that is, a nice way to 'logging out')
:slightly_smiling_face:
anyway till that time DELETE works just fine :slightly_smiling_face:
[ BTW: was just (also) saying that impersonation is usually, PersonA being able to pretend/impersonate as PersonB. Just terminology... ]
Check if DELETE works... otherwise, we'll try to expedite it.
(I know that there is already underlying work for it, that's why I'm saying this)

Got your point there..  
And will check this DELETE thing and let you all know.
Thank you Jonanthan, Thank you Srini

3. Yes, you can use affiliations to represent group levels
Which can give you a better way of grouping, rather than just by using roles.
2. I’d use `attr.GetValueFrom()`
Just for context, at some point the Attributes work was ‘pulled up’ to a shared location in fabric so that it can be more easily reused. This is why it is under `core/crypto/attributes`
It’s a straight forward API with a good test coverage (at least as a unit), so sure, please go ahead.

<@U1WUAQJVC>: HTH ^^^
<@U1HBFGDPV> Hi Vincent
Yes, thanks for clarifying. Didn’t want to answer yes/no above before understanding.

Something that is good to bear in mind is that in most (use-) cases, an enrollment (obtaining an ECert) is an action that is needed less frequently than transacting… (for which one needs/requires a TCert)
In general (and again, depends on the case), ECerts are viewed as a much long(er) lasting certificates/proof/evidence.
It might be easier to think about an ECert a (gym ?!?) membership subscription.
Or a driving license (which can serve as an identity) or any other ‘membership card'
… afterwhich, an entity can transact (many times).
TCerts are shorter term certs, especially in comparison to ECerts… so for optimizing (again, depending on the use-case) it might be better to focus on the TCert generation.
Another point on this, is that you can request a batch of TCerts, just like the ClientSDK (NodeJS) supports.
This way you can obtain/generate several TCerts at a time, and use them later (while they haven’t expired, etc.)
Another (final) comment from me, this time round, is that even though ECerts are based on X.509 v3 there is still some internal state that fabric maintains/manages..
One’s registration (EnrollmentID) is later on used in several places… you can take a look at the `membersrvc.yaml` file to see some of these (e.g., `lukas` from `bank_a`)
So at the moment it might be more than just issuing a/some x.509 v3 cert.
We were/are thinking of abstracting this a bit more, providing entry points - there are some documents in Jira about it, but it’d still require some work.
OK, OK, last one, I promise!
If you already have a trusted 3rd party, then the better/easier way would be to delegate the responsibility to other CAs. Meaning, the trusted 3rd party does not need to issue ALL the certs.
It is more scalable to have a few ‘delegated’ ECAs/TCAs… and might be the recommended way, rather than you writing up your own ECert-generation logic.
I’ll stop here (as promised ;-)), but we can discuss/develop this more. Give us a shout.

<@U11MANG9G> my suggestion was that the linux model of UID and GID makes perfect sense for the basic identity management (regardless of whether the GID it's called affiliation of affinity). I also think the idea of building encryption pre-key trees on a group hierarchy is a powerful 'audit' feature. Another addition to consider is permission masks(flags) related to read/write operations(transactions). Last but not least delegate roles also is a great fit for enterprise identity management systems where designated leads can create agent-level accounts.
<@U11MANG9G> let me know if that makes sense to you
Yup, this is what it was designed for… same for the pre-key. The masks are not for read/write, but are a stonger/richer property that is used for selective revealing of information.
The key feature here is delegation, which makes it both easy to administer (actively manage) users and for auditing.
I was just surprised to read/hear about a/the new terms, while not seeing any proposal.
So, yes, I agree <@U1CTBUNEN> and it makes sense to me.

<@U1CTBUNEN> : We are going to keep the concept and implementation of Pre-Key as it stands today(We might add some other variant , if that seems appropriate). So , you should not be worried on that front. Our next problem to solve is how to manage those pre-Keys etc. Also , something like delegation , can be handled at Enterprise Level etc. by virtue of LDAP implementation (which is defacto standard for user management). For users with roles that cannot be tied back to Enterprise Role , we have to provide those capabilities at Memebership Services level.
The doc mentioned above does not talk about these in details , but we'll produce a doc to share with community.

You should read doc keeping in mind that users might not be using full blown capabilities being offered by membership services , e.g. some user(s) might not want to use ECert being created by Membership services, they want to bring their own. Some users might not want to use membership services at all. The doc provides abstraction as to what will be offered by Memebership Services , giving flexibility to users to choose from.

So , memebership service should hook into Enterprise SIEM(Security Incident Event Management) system.

Hi, question regarding mbrsvc architecture in v1: what will happen if somebody gain control over one of the meberservcies instances? Theoretically it can start issue new certificates and new peers will join network, which can take a control over the network? This was an issue in v.05 but now we mbrsvc is distributed so how this case is prevented is there any use case description for such scenario? Which architecture should customer use to prevent such scenario?
You are talking about a sybil attack by adding new peers when one membersrvc is compromised
this will not be possible for the following reason

The blockchain network is bootstrapped with multiple CA root certificates which everyone agrees upon and will be part of the genesis block.  Also part of the genesis block is a policy for adding new CA root certificates.  Let’s assume the policy is the unanimous policy.
In order to add a new root CA certificate to the network, you must have the signature/approval of all existing CAs
assuming “unanimous” policy to add new root CA certs

Now, transactions are sent to peer’s yes, but the endorsement policy is based on a signature by a CA.   So no matter how many peers there are associated with a CA / membership services / COP server, the endorsement policies count at the CA level, not at the peer level
So in a nutshell, 2 things prevent a sybil attack:
1) Endorsement policies count root CA signatures (aka “participants” in some of the doc), not peer signatures
2) Adding new root CAs (aka “participants”) require approval by other CAs based upon some agreed upon policy
I hope this makes sense
Thanks <@U0S5KF44D>

<@U0PB67X4K> just peeked into FAB-635 and see it talks about T/ECERTS … let me read that first

to answer you questions, CFSSL provides basic PKI capabilities for issuing and signing certificates, revocation, etc.  Issuing an ECert is straightforward since ECerts are pretty much just standard issue signed  X509 elliptic curve certificates.  TCerts in their current form are more complicated in that they are "derived" from ECerts.   CFSSL can of course easily sign the TCerts but generating them is another issue.   FAB-635 proposes some alternative models for TCert generation to avoid having to modify HSMs but at least one of the options (option 2) would have make it quite easy to extend CFSSL to support

text: Hi everyone,

So as some of you noticed, the `feature/ca` branch is broken. We have reported it here:
<https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-893>
There are a few options we have discussed:
1. To update the Makefile, resolve the “broken” external dependency which causes the build to fail (at the `vagrant up` stage, which calls make)
2. To merge `master` into the `feature/ca` so that the branch starts working with the updated image (16.04, etc.)
3. To actually strip down the build in this specific branch, so that it does not carry the full build/stack. That is, to just build and run only the Fabric COP related tests at this point.
<@U0PB67X4K> and <@U0KM61BCP> are aware of these. I suggested to spend some time on it, and see if I had a quick fix.

If someone could pick this up, that would be great - I don’t have a preference (1 and 2 might actually be quicker, and the merge from master to feature/ca currently has no conflicts). Whatever works - so that we can start merging code/changesets to a working/building branch back again.
Thank you.
^^^ <@U0S5KF44D>, <@U1KJY9BJQ> [, <@U0KPFAZNF>, <@U0PB67X4K>, <@U0KM61BCP>, … }
I am in the process of moving all of this to the fabric-cop repo.  Once this is complete, we can do away with feature/ca
<@U0S5KF44D> this works! (yes, this work will have get done at some point, so sooner rather than later is probably the better approach here). Thank you.
Will probably be much better to travel-light :wink:, and not carry so much with it.
yes, that's the plan ... thanks
Sure thing.
woo hoo!
<@U2MCH9EEB|crazybit> has joined the channel
<@U2T4S6X6C|jd> has joined the channel
<@U2JCD7N7R|georgeo> has joined the channel

We are suggesting that Membership Service will refer to the old implementation (ie for 0.5 and 0.6), COP will be the new word for default CA provider for version 1 to help prevent confusion,.. The only thing the fabric  for 1.0 knows about is CA provider
We are in ad hoc meeting with Keith and Elli

The CA provider interface with target to make it visible to anyone such that CA provider can be pluggable.  The default one is the COP.  The high level interface appears on fab289.   A definition in go lang to be used later on by peer code has been done by Keith.  And then, as soon as we finalize, Keith is waiting for feedback.  That interface will be the building blocks for the peer functionality (peer that checks proposals submitted by client and transactions received by the ordering service).
There could be a simplification of the API- what peer should be used by SDK, what should be used by peer we need to make sure is in .  And of course exposure to chaincode.

What is missing or is not clear is definition of nodejs that picked up by Client SDK side.  WE have been talking to those in SDK team such as Jim Zhang- there is part of this API that has to talk to the COP server.  Again, this is the API that talks to COP server- register, enroll,etc,..?
egister and enroll- that will not be built in peer itself.  It will be a COP executable where it will call the COP server.

For part of this api that runs in the peer- a simple api that says we load key here, we load list of certificates,.. and that is all that's on the peer API (ie the import functions) .  By separating the API- the peer API versus the SDK API is important to make clear.  Both command line tool will do register and enroll and SDK will do this over rest- there will be functionally equivalent.

COP based interface-> we are not going to touch the server side of COP, or the client side (ie nodejs.)  For client side of nodejs sdk, SDK programming team is going to have to ask if they needs help on crypto primatives, but the SDK team owns that for now.  SDK team will have to ask Elli and team if they need help.  (ie signing identity)  Will the challenge during enroll- does that change dramatically from COP from membership services? For the current option, it won't change much at all.  We are supporting the HSM friendly version, which is going to be simpler on the client side.  But the HSM part only involves the early part of generating key pair, but from that point SDK has to talk to COP server for enroll?  The current method of TCERT generation requires that you use derivation keys on the client.  That won't work for HSM.  So there will be a change to support as option 2 according to document which basically means you are generating a bunch of certificate signing requests on the client side.  They are all being signed as a batch and being sent back.   That part will have to change with nodejs.sdk.
There is a CSR that is part of enroll that can be sent.  So you are asking does enroll change?  Today it does not involve CSR- it's the challenge mechanism.  Enroll does change for the node sdk.

first thing is integration of blockchain cyrpto service provider -- enroll, generate identities, sign,.. all these operations will need to be changed based on separations to refer to crypto service provider.  There has to be 2 crypto providers- one that Angelo built in go lang and an HSM based which is essentially conversing and relaying any kind of timing request or key generation request to HSM card.  One step is to have all the crypto in the SDK accessing single crypto library.  If someone wants to substitute this library with some custom implementation, they are able to do this by adding new provider.

Centralization of the crypto libraries happen at a very low level.  Then, the modification of code to export this interface that is generic enough so enable CA providers which provides at higher level in a pluggable way.

From  nodejs,.. you can't it's go lang.  You would need to provide implementation in nodejs... That's the next question.  We currently have crypto primitives.   ARe you planning on building for nodejs.

if the change on javascript side to talk to golang and is just a matter of code refactoring- the crypto code is already in node sdk, but it's a matter of the bccsp interface.  With new code base start- we are refactoring the existing into new code blase- implementation doesn't change, but just refactor that it does apply to bccsp.

For Java SDK- there is JCE apis-- do we want them to be compatible- or have java implementing without JSSE?  Not sure... Java comes with a nice crypto infrastructure- and you can go with that and be more compatible with that.  That seems like you would not implement another interface, but of course the BCCSP- if it has to be everywhere- then it would have to be done.  But because BCCSP- it provides the basic crypto algorithim.

For JAva side- the way we change providers for go lang for BCCSP- it would be nice to present the same upfront on how people program to it- even if the backend is a little different.  The Java JCE is meant to abstract out the crypto providers- to me, it's equivalent to BCCSP, but perhaps the abstraction layer is a bit different.  AS a client talking to server, the interface will be abstracted as BCCSP, but the java code can be used applied to JCE implementation, but should also implement the BCCSP protocol.  To switch out Java providers- there is a property file you modify at run time.  if in config file, you want a software provider, fips provider,etc,.. when the JVM comes up you make the decision.  If you present the configs to everyone, to a user it looks uniform, but inside we can take care of the differences.

How similar are nodejs.sdk and Java SDK?   Java code is different structurewise how implementations and interfaces are done, but in the end the Java team should be able to take what nodejs, sdk -- what structure for endorsement, how you unmarshall the data, and how you structure input to the order.  All that should come across different SDKs.

How do you see this work between JCE and BCCSP side ?  Is there a proto adapter on top of java sdk with adapter on top with JCE?  Let's take registration as an example.  We know the client sdk has to provide method for registering the user.  This is the thing that matters from the developer .  The way it's implemented it does not care.  In Java, they would expect it to be implemented directly to JCE.  On top of Java, you implement the protocol.  Every time there is a crytpographic method- you just go to JCE.  In Golang, you implement the COP interface- you go to the BCCSP.

Basically whether you are using JCE on Java or implementing BCCSP with node, the document it presents to server is the same- whether it's a certificate in 509 format or crypto encrypted challenge.  Both providers of interfaces need to understand.
we have protobufs that marshall and unmarshall that is agnostic to the platform.  Let's say I'm a client developer- do we need to adhere to interfaces for BCCSP--

In general you should follow the interface to cop- now, how you use the crytpographic algorithim- put your self in client SDK user.  I am developer who wants to use SDK- I would not see anything related to crypto.  I would only see interfaces for doing enrollment, getting identity.  I don't care what protocol.  As long as i use the COP service , it should be the same
From our point of view- the fabric protocol should be HSM friendly- client sdk should not care about this- but should know about the options.  They should use the interfaces in the same way.

The BCCSP implementation- do we have augmented implementation that factored go code on the server side like based on RSA for example?  do we have to change the BCCSP to use RSA?  Now that we defined interface, how do we know interface can support other crypto suites?  If we do, do we have alternate implementation that we can test?  The BCCSP can provide multiple algorithims- the problem of how to use the algorithims must be moved to the fabric- so the fabric has to recognize RSA,etc,. and other algorithims.  You built interface so rest of fabric can use interface- ECSA or RSA.  Do we have at least 2 implementations of the provider interface for the algorthims to test out the interface works and is sufficient?  And also the client to test against the implementations for testing purposes. ... The BCCSP- the software based implementation ECDSA and HMAC and others,...we have not implemented RSA yet.  But there are methods that are generic , but think it's good to have other primitives implemented through BCCSP.

We need to have at least 1 more implementation than ECSDA plus SHAR256,etc,.. so we know interface we defined is good.  And the rest of the peers get all they need to support different algorithms.  If no alternate implementation,.. how do we know?  We could provide RSA supported x509... we can do this (please note sorry about spelling)

Why don't we have a document on BCCSP in community discussing this?  Maybe a googledoc?  There are folks in China who do want a different way to do things due to country requirements.  Maybe this helps with the review.

And then maybe the folks in China interested in this can contribute what they want.  They are very motivated to provide a different implementation based on HSM 123  as this is required by the government.
Russia is also the same.
From client SDK perspective- we are doing a register enroll- we have to do a go implementation for the cli, but we also have to have the node version and the java
For next week- we should be able to finish the endorsement ordering for both deploy, invoke, and query for transactions.... but not sure all the security work we can get done.

Could we run self signed certificate- could we use for sign and verify in 1 week away? Part of the API- they can plug in their own certificate-- so can our own CA be a self signed certificate for peers and on the orders?  If you use self-sign there is non CA. So yes client can use self sign, and COP would let anything go for certificate check- but we can exercise the sign and verify function.   We can have cop server running enroll for the peer and use the actual certificate and key that ist stored to do the signing.  This assumes the peer specific code can import that- just use the COP CLI, which is what we intend to use and get it downloaded to file and peer that Elli and team are loading that into a class.  It's currently equivalent to identity and signing identity in go to create the real signature in the peer.. then in the SDK code, you can't do that for next week, but the current code there to do primitives would not be difficult to verify a signature.  The main thing is we have to change from GRPC to REST.... that's the real issue.  HMM,.. i was just talking getting things back from the peer, but you not talking to the cop server.  If you don't have to do register or enroll- we could probably do, but sending endorsement and sending transactions-doesn't that involve COP?  On client side, you have to have member ID, you have to sign transaction and send through... But let's say we use COP CLI where client is running, we could enroll of web application. So then your code would load from file also .
Are we going to involve TCERT? NO
That may work to do enroll and registration through CLI and we could have run files for private key to sign.
The format that you are saving - is that the same as the SDK as we were doing before?  let's discuss this more.
If it's not the same and it's throw away code- we won't do this.
Is it a valid scenario to do the CLI to enroll and then have SDK to support that file format?  Seems like that should not be a scenario we should not support.

The other thing is the one Hyperledger member thought of having certificates on the ledger.  The things that are going on the ledger is the trusted root CA.   We would run the COP CLI to put a certificate somewhere on the file system to load.  But what should happen is that it should be getting it off the ledger for all of it's trusted roots.  The private key that it gets is from the filesystem.  The trusted roots certificate for validating signatures..
That then dovetails into bootstrap. At boostrap we would need to collect certificates and boostrap orderer and peer to be able to build up the genesis block.

Do you agree with separating the parts of the API in peer, chaincode and SDK Elli?   Elli take parts of that API need to be done in chaincode... Keith could try to do this for the peer and for the SDK.  Keith feels there need to be separate APIs,.. and then Elli and team would implement the peer and chaincode parts.

Has anyone given a thought to FIPS certification to crypto?  Vlad has some ideas on this.  Evidently we have team in australia who certifies crypto... we could have a fips certified crypto... This BCCSP work- we could get FIPS certification if we get GSKIT into there.
FIPS is important given every bank and government requires this.  BCCSP is step in right direction- software provider, HSM provider, and a FIPS provider.

I found a work-around. I replaced tca.cert, tca.priv, and tca.pub in /var/hyperledger/production/.membersrvc/ to the new ones, which were obtained from another membersrvc recently installed.
I also replaced tca.cert.chain in /var/hyperledger/production/crypto/validator/YOUR_VP_NAME/ks/raw/ and /var/hyperledger/production/crypto/client/ENROLLMENT_ID/ks/raw/ with the tca.cert

for all the users and VPs. Fortunately, I am not using HFC. In the case of HFC clients, I suppose one need to convert PEM format -> byte buffer -> hex string and update the key files /tmp/keyValStore, but I haven't tried yet.
thanks.

>peers will be expecting a validated enrollId on most API requests. Therefore, the first step is we need to use the /registrar API endpoint to register an enrollId. [November 10th, 2016 4:06 AM] garisingh: Sorry for the wide blast here, but while I was reviewing stuff, thought I should send out a note on things which will make life easier for the maintainers and will help contributions be merged more quickly:

1) Please make sure to reference a JIRA item in your commits - especially for new functionality

2) Let's try to add a little more detail to some of the JIRA entries - one line entries / descriptions don't help us understand what contribution is trying to achieve

3) When people make comments in gerrit, once you address them please mark them as done (by clicking in the comment and hitting done  :slightly_smiling_face:  )

4) You'll notice that we push back a lot on lack of tests - please test locally and use a coverage tool to see where you stand

5) Run linters, go import, etc to reduce CI failures

Sorry for the wide blast here, but while I was reviewing stuff, thought I should send out a note on things which will make life easier for the maintainers and will help contributions be merged more quickly:

1) Please make sure to reference a JIRA item in your commits - especially for new functionality

2) Let's try to add a little more detail to some of the JIRA entries - one line entries / descriptions don't help us understand what contribution is trying to achieve

3) When people make comments in gerrit, once you address them please mark them as done (by clicking in the comment and hitting done  :slightly_smiling_face:  )

4) You'll notice that we push back a lot on lack of tests - please test locally and use a coverage tool to see where you stand

5) Run linters, go import, etc to reduce CI failures

<@U31TA64TT> If you enrolled via the node SDK and then tried to enroll via the REST API with the same enrollment ID and secret, then the failure is because the secret is a one-time password.  Since you already used the secret via the node SDK, it can't be used again unless you remove membersrvc's state by stopping membersrvc, removing the /var/hyperledger/production/.membersrvc directory (this is the default directory, but can be overridden in membersrvc.yaml), and then restart membersrvc.

That said, note 2 things: 1) The REST API is not secure and will be going away, but I assume you are just playing around with it for now and 2) in v1 of fabric, we will be providing a REST-based replacement for membership services based on CFSSL which is called COP.   There is a fabric-cop channel and you can see some info for COP at <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TRYHcaT8yMn8MZlDtreqzkDcXx0WI50AV2JpAcvAM5w>

Question: Will data lost if chaincode get upgrade? Suppose we deployed chaincode_A_V1. We put data to hyperledger fabric blockchain. Suppose we need to upgrade chaincode_v2. All Data will be lost. Correct? (Because it seems that data cannot be shared in different chaincodes, correct?)
Or we need data migration from chaincode_A_v1 to chaincode_A_v2 ?

<@U2Y2V95D2> - technically the data is not "lost" (meaning it is not deleted / removed) and would still be accessible from the chaincode associated with it.  But what you are really asking is whether or not Fabric supports upgrading chaincode.   Up through v0.6.x, the answer is no (unless you are working in development mode).  In v1 (which is what is under current development) the answer is yes and this does mean that you are actually "replacing" the previous chaincode with new chaincode and it will have access to the same data
Thanks <@U0PB67X4K> . So, we have to wait for v1 (do we have any target timeline for v1?). Thanks.

Question: And single point of failure problem exist in membership-services, right?   And we only have one, people might argue who should/can this superpower to administer the membership-services. Is it correct? Thanks.

V1 is currently under active development and there is actually working code in the master branch.  we are targeting getting an "end to end" preview out by the end of the year and of course we'll have incremental drops after that on the path to hopefully having a candidate v1 release in the late March timeframe

in terms of membership services, in the V1 architecture we will also be supporting multiple identity providers (meaning you can have multiple entities issuing the requisite crypto material) and we'll also be providing a fault tolerant reference implementation as well.   The "new" version of membership services is actually called "Fabric COP" and has its own Gerrit repo  aptly named `fabric-cop`
Also, COP is not any abbreviation of anything, we did intend to name it COP

The TCert is where you get the ‘right’ to transact. The ACL is a “trick” or feature that allows users to restrict others from running their code. The best way to not allow someone to transact is actually at the TCert level.

<@U2DHRR4TE>, just for context, this whole TCert/permissioning was David’s <@U16Q0J0E6> design early on. The ACL in the chaincode is very separate (as you may be able to tell).

ok so to summarise what you are saying:

There is no list of people who are allowed to deploy _per se_ but instead what we have is this ACL system which bestows the ability to perform certain actions to users so long as they are known to be part of a group which is permitted to perform these actions. If you are a real user (and therefore have a real ecert) and you submit a real transaction (i.e. with a valid tcert) and your ecert is assosiated with a group that is allowed to do the thing you want to do, you can do it.
Yes [transacting with a TCert], indeed
To make it a bit more complicated :wink:...
… you can use this framework for a richer functionality, with more assertions/claims that can be part of a TCert… and so that validators will be able to check for these.
E.g., maybe I’ll (one day) have the “best truck driver of 2016” attribute on my C.V. and `TrucksBrothersCorp` will confirm that (attribute/value) in one of the signed certs.
Then you might have the logic of “Of course I will allow the "best truck driver of 2016” to do XYZ.

___
That’s where you can extend the above paragraph of yours with the attributes mechanism, which is very powerful.
As you can simply “respect”/“accept” claims that are confirmed by an organization - and these are not limited to just a role. They can be a lot of things.
But that last bit was a bit extra curricular/more about the initial/global vision.
